questions.text: A child with absent thymus and presented with a tetany. Which of the following marked areas in the given image is defective in this Condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C The given clinical features suggest the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Thymus and parathyroid are absent in this patient suggesting defect in 3 rd pharyngeal pouch marked as ‘C' in the given image.

Highyeild:

DiGeorge syndrome Caused by deletion of chromosome 22q11 Defects (CATCH – 22) C left palate A bnormal faces T hymus aplasia leading to T cell deficiency C ardiac defects H ypocalcemia secondary to parathyroid aplasia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- The given clinical features suggest the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Thymus and parathyroid are absent in this patient suggesting defect in 3 rd pharyngeal pouch marked as ‘C' in the given image, therefore option A, B and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

DiGeorge syndrome, more accurately known by a broader term — 22q11.2 deletion syndrome — is a disorder caused when a small part of chromosome 22 is missing. This deletion results in the poor development of several body systems. Medical problems commonly associated with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome include heart defects, poor immune system function, a cleft palate, complications related to low levels of calcium in the blood, and delayed development with behavioral and emotional problems.

questions.text: Covid may spread to meninges and lead to intracranial complications through which of the following marked areas?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

C SARS-COV2 reaches Brian via cribriform plate and olfactory bulb marked in the given figure as ‘C' Neurological sequelae to severe Covid-19 include encephalitis, demyelination, neuropathy and stroke. Refractory respiratory failure can occur if the virus invades medullary cardio respiratory center.

Highyeild:

A fractured cribriform plate can result in olfactory dysfunction, septal hematoma, cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhoea (CSF rhinorrhoea), and possibly infection which can lead to meningitis. CSF rhinorrhoea (clear fluid leaking from the nose) is very serious and considered a medical emergency. Aging can cause the openings in the cribriform plate to close, pinching olfactory nerve fibers. A reduction in olfactory receptors, loss of blood flow, and thick nasal mucus can also cause an impaired sense of smell.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- B is Foramen magnum Option C- D is Optic canal Option D-A is Foramen rotundum SARS-COV2 reaches Brian via cribriform plate and olfactory bulb marked in the given figure as ‘C', therefore option A, C and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

The cribriform plate is perforated by olfactory foramina, which allow for the passage of the olfactory nerves to the roof of the nasal cavity.This conveys information from smell receptors to the brain. The foramina at the medial part of the groove allow the passage of the nerves to the upper part of the nasal septum while the foramina at the lateral part transmit the nerves to the superior nasal concha.

questions.text: Structure forming the superior boundary of foramen marked is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Caudate lobe of liver The structure marked in the given image is epiploic foramen. Caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior border of epiploic foramen. Epiploic foramen connects lesser sac to the greater sac.

Highyeild:

Relations of epiploic foramen Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. Anterior – Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein and common bile duct. Posterior – Inferior vena cava, Right suprarenal gland, Body of T12 vertebra Superior – Caudate lobe of the liver Inferior – 1 st part of duodenum

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- Duodenum 1 st part of duodenum lies inferior to epiploic foramen. Option B- Lesser omentum Hepatoduodenal ligament containing hepatic artery, portal vein and common bile duct lies anterior to epiploic foramen. Option C- IVC Inferior vena cava, Right suprarenal gland, Body of T12 vertebra, lies posterior to epiploic foramen.

Extraedge:

The epiploic foramen, also called the foramen of Winslow, is a small vertical passage between the greater sac (peritoneal cavity proper) and the lesser sac (omental bursa), allowing communication between these two spaces. The foramen is described as the opening to the lesser sac located "between the two great veins of the abdomen (portal vein and inferior vena cava).

questions.text: A woman presented to the hospital with loss of sensation in right upper and lower limbs. She also complains of shooting pain from her fingers, the right shoulder and a burning sensation when she touches cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B The given clinical features suggest involvement of thalamus. Thalamus pain syndrome/Dejerine Roussy syndrome Due to occlusion of thalamus and thalamo geniculate branches It is characterised by C/L hemisensory loss which starts as numbness and progresses to cause severe burning pain in the affected regions. The pain responds poorly to analgesics Anticonvulsants such as Carbamazepine or gabapentin or tricyclic antidepressants may be beneficial.

Highyeild:

Thalamic pain syndrome or central post-stroke pain can occur when there are disruptions of one of the pathways of the brain that affects the sensation of temperature. There can be burning or tingling pain. Also, significant discomfort with temperature changes is a concern for thalamic pain syndrome following a stroke.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B- D is Pons Option C- A is Caudate Nucleus Option D- C is substantia nigra The given clinical features suggest involvement of thalamus,therefore option B, C and D are incorrect answers.

Extraedge:

ejerine-Roussy is a rare pain syndrome. Individuals with emerging Dejerine–Roussy syndrome usually report they are experiencing unusual pain or sensitivity that can be allodynic in nature or triggered by seemingly unrelated stimuli (sounds, tastes). Symptoms are typically lateralized and may include vision loss or loss of balance (position sense). Workup should be performed by a neurologist and brain imaging to look for evidence of infarction or tumor should be obtained.

questions.text: Which of the following are the branches of anterior division of the internal Iliac artery? Superior gluteal artery Inferior gluteal artery Superior vesical artery Middle rectal artery Inferior vesical artery Vaginal artery Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 Internal Iliac artery divides into anterior and posterior trunks at the superior border of greater sciatic foramen. Branches of anterior trunk of the internal iliac artery Obturator artery Superior vesical artery Inferior vesical artery Inferior gluteal artery Middle rectal artery Vaginal artery (females) Uterine artery (females) Internal pudendal artery

Highyeild:

Branches of posterior trunk of internal Iliac artery Iliolumbar artery Lateral sacral artery Superior gluteal artery

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- 1,2,3 and 5 Option B- 2, 3 and 5 Option D- 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 Inferior gluteal artery, Superior vesical artery, Middle rectal artery, Inferior vesical artery, and Vaginal artery all are branches of anterior division of internal iliac artery except superior gluteal artery.

Extraedge:

The common iliac artery bifurcates into the internal iliac artery and external iliac artery at the level of the pelvic brim anterior to the sacroiliac joint.

questions.text: A 6 month old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician does CSF sampling through the marked structure. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scalp, dura, arachnoid The marked structure in the image is anterior fontanelle. The structures pierced in ventricular tapping are scalp, dura and arachnoid. A 25 gauge butterfly needle is inserted through the anterolateral aspect of the anterior fontanelle (away from the midline, avoiding the superior sagittal sinus)

Highyeild:

The layers pierced to reach subarachnoid space in the order are : Skin Superficial fascia Aponeurosis Loose areolar tissue Pericranium Dura mater Arachnoid membrane

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Scalp, epicranium, endocranium, dura Option C. Pericranium, dura, arachnoid Option D. Scalp, Synchondral membrane, dura, arachnoid The marked structure in the image is anterior fontanelle. The structures pierced in ventricular tapping are scalp, dura and arachnoid, therefore

Extraedge:

By three months of age, the anterior fontanel is closed in 1 percent of infants; by 12 months, it is closed in 38 percent; and by 24 months, it is closed in 96 percent. Anterior fontanels tend to close earlier in boys than in girls; the initial size of the fontanel is not a predictor of when it will close.
